content: The "NATO Freedom Consolidation Act of 2007" emphasizes NATO's role in promoting democratic transformation in Central and Eastern Europe and addressing security challenges in the post-Cold War era. It highlights the importance of integrating emerging democracies into existing European structures for lasting stability and security. NATO's contribution to security in the face of terrorism and weapons of mass destruction is crucial. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 and the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 emphasized the importance of inviting countries to become full NATO members to contribute to the security of the North Atlantic area. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 and the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 emphasized the importance of inviting countries to become full NATO members to contribute to the security of the North Atlantic area. In 1998, Congress declared that the process of enlarging NATO should not be limited to Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia, but should also include Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria. The NATO Participation Act of 1994 and the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 emphasized inviting countries to become full NATO members for security. In 1998, Congress expanded the enlargement process to include more countries. The Gerald B. H. Solomon Freedom Consolidation Act of 2002 endorsed further NATO enlargement. At the Madrid Summit in 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO leaders pledged to continue welcoming new members who can uphold the principles of the Treaty and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. They stated that no European democratic country fulfilling the Treaty's objectives will be excluded from consideration for membership. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several countries declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement. They emphasized that membership for any of these countries would be a success for all and for Europe. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all European democracies seeking security and freedom, emphasizing the importance of not using nations as pawns and advancing the cause of freedom during a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001. At the Prague Summit in November 2002, several European countries were invited to join NATO in the second round of enlargement since the Cold War. Former President Clinton also emphasized NATO's openness to all emerging democracies in Europe during a speech in Detroit in 1996. At the Istanbul Summit in June 2004, NATO reaffirmed its commitment to welcoming European democracies willing to meet membership obligations, as stated in the Washington Treaty. The US Senate ratified protocols for Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia to join NATO. Heads of state and government reaffirmed NATO's Open Door Policy, welcoming progress made by Albania, Croatia, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia towards NATO membership. NATO will continue to assess each country's candidacy individually based on reform goals pursued through the Membership Action Plan. Georgia and Ukraine are aspiring to join NATO and are actively working with the organization and its members to meet the criteria for membership. The progress of aspirants towards NATO membership will be reviewed at the next Summit based on reports provided by NATO Foreign Ministers. President George W. Bush expressed support for Georgia's NATO membership during a speech in 2006, stating that it would benefit both Georgia and the alliance. NATO Secretary General announced an Intensified Dialogue on membership with Georgia after a meeting in 2006. Ukraine's President also declared NATO membership as a goal and expressed a desire to conclude a Membership Action Plan at a summit in 2005. At the Riga Summit in November 2006, NATO reaffirmed its open door policy for new members, stating that all European democratic countries could be considered for Membership Action Plan or admission based on their performance. NATO Foreign Ministers were directed to keep the process under review. NATO reaffirms commitment to Georgia and Ukraine's aspirations for membership, highlighting the importance of their Intensified Dialogues and Distinctive Partnership. Ukraine's contributions to common security are appreciated, including participation in NATO-led operations and regional cooperation efforts. NATO encourages Ukraine to continue contributing to regional security and supports far-reaching reform efforts in national security, defense, defense-industrial sector, and anti-corruption measures. The alliance welcomes an Intensified Dialogue with Georgia and its peacekeeping efforts, urging progress in political, economic, and military reforms, including judicial reform and peaceful conflict resolution. Engagement with all parties in the region is emphasized. Congress calls for the timely admission of Albania, Croatia, Georgia, Macedonia (FYROM), and Ukraine to NATO to promote security and stability in Europe. This is in line with previous expressions of support for NATO enlargement. The text chunk supports NATO enlargement to include European democracies willing to meet membership responsibilities, as expressed in various summit declarations. It endorses the vision of further NATO enlargement articulated by President George W. Bush and former President William J. Clinton, urging allies to work with the US towards this goal. The text chunk supports NATO enlargement by designating Albania, Croatia, Georgia, Macedonia (FYROM), and Ukraine as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The Republic of Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia (FYROM) are designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Ukraine, along with Albania, Croatia, Georgia, and Macedonia (FYROM), is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. This designation is in addition to Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia, which were designated under the NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996. The text discusses the designation of Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Bulgaria, and Slovakia as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. It also mentions that other countries can be designated by the President for assistance under the same program. "Under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, funds for fiscal year 2008 are authorized for assistance to Albania, Croatia, Georgia, Macedonia (FYROM), and Ukraine."
